Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Story: I glance at the clock as I rush out the door, my work boots thudding on the steps. The construction site is a ten-minute walk, and the safety briefing starts in two. I can’t be late again—last time, the foreman gave me a warning about team discipline. But as I pass the row of trash bins, I notice ours is only half-full. Mrs. Lee, my elderly neighbor, always struggles to wheel it out, and she’s mentioned how much she appreciates when I help. If I leave it, she’ll have to drag it herself, and I know how steep the curb is. But if I stop to help, I’ll be late for the briefing, and the team will have to wait for me. My mind races: be a good neighbor or a reliable worker? I stand frozen, the weight of both expectations pressing on me, heart pounding as the seconds tick by.
